outputs.output_descr: East and Southern Africa HIV Rights & Gender and Sexual Diversity

Integrating HIV/AIDS concerns into national development processes. Socioeconomic determinants and MDGs: To sustain and accelerate gains made in HIV prevention in the sub region,  we will support countries to better understand the socio-economic drivers of HIV and to respond with appropriate structural interventions, within broader MDG and national development plans. The coming into force of the Free Trade Agreement in the SADC and EAC regions could trigger increased cross-border movements of people and there is potential for increased HIV risk and vulnerability.  In addition, the global economic crisis of 2009 saw the upward trend in resources for HIV flat lining, raising concerns in the sub region about the sustainability of current AIDS programmes mainly dependent on external funding and the need to explore other option to sustain AIDS programmes. In 2011, we will therefore: (a) partner with SADC to support a regional-wide definition of priority areas and indicators for five key sectors to enable them mainstream HIV, gender and human rights related priorities into their plans more effectively; (b) Support countries to strengthen the management of health and HIV vulnerabilities and impacts associated with the implementation of capital projects especially mining, road construction, and dam construction through EIAs; (c) Provide technical assistance for a regional based analysis and unpacking of the global MDGs report to inform SADC and other REC planning; (d)  provide financial support for a SADC study on the impact of the FTA on HIV and (e) on request, support country specific activities to help countries plan more sustainable responses to HIV/AIDS.

Strengthening the governance component of AIDS responses. Coordination and accountability: Given the multisectoral nature of HIV and AIDS countries and their development partners agree that coordination of the national AIDS response also requires a mechanism that brings together the different sectors. This is further reinforced by the 'three ones' principle which requires countries to have  One national AIDS coordinating authority with a broad-based multi-sectoral mandate. To this end most countries in the region established National AIDS Councils that are entrusted to lead and coordinate the national response. However, following recent developments at the global and national levels particularly around the financial architecture and epidemilogical advances and political contexts it has become necessary to revisit the effectiveness of the AIDS coordination in countries. UNDP in partnership with UNAIDS and the WB was working on a Sector Institutional Assessment that looks into the achivements and challenges of coordination in various countries. While this work helped to understand the many challenges that countries face, lessons from the work in 2009 and 2010 indicate the need for more country owned and led processes. Accordingly in 2011 UNDP will work with other regional level partners such as WB, UNAIDS and SADC to respond to specfic country needs and requests in strengthening coordination. This work will be linked to and benfit from currently ongoing global disussions and thinking on national ownership and coordination and the role of the UN family and other partners.
